fields.text:
What is the Curiosity Machine?

Curiosity Machine is a community of scientists, engineers and children creating together. Through this online learning platform children are inspired and equipped to create their own inventions with the support of trained and qualified mentors.


In each challenge, children progress through the Engineering Design Process with support from a trained mentor who guides and encourages them to persist through failure and bring their ideas to reality.


Engineering Design Challenges

Our challenges are based on innovative science and engineering. They also:

  • need only simple, low-cost materials (most can be obtained at a grocery store);
  • are open-ended and have “low walls with high ceilings”, meaning they are easy to start but also invite everyone to keep building and to develop more complex design solutions;
  • emphasize that science is a creative process; not just a collection of facts.

Who is part of our community?


Families learn together and continue inventing at home. Parents explore alongside their children, making comparisons between what they learn and daily life.


Educators with a passion for making learning a fun process of exploration. No science background required!


Professional scientists and engineers from all over the world inspire the next generation of inventors, modeling curiosity, creativity, and persistence.

Our Mission

Our mission is to inspire children to develop their natural curiosity and hone their investigative skills to become inventors, creators, builders and engineers. We support children, parents, and educators with fun project-based science lessons, making learning and doing science accessible and enjoyable. We emphasize the engineering design process because we care deeply about helping children become more persistent and creative in the face of failure, so they are better equipped to handle setbacks and frustration throughout their lives. The Curiosity Machine is powered by Iridescent, a science education non-profit that creates and delivers powerful science, engineering, and technology education to underprivileged children.

Supported by


Content Partner

Some videos you find in the Curiosity machine are produced by Science Friday, a trusted source for news and entertaining stories about science. It started as a radio show, created in 1991 by host and executive producer Ira Flatow. Since then, it has grown into much more: SciFri produces award-winning digital videos and publishes original web content covering everything from octopus camouflage to cooking on Mars. Science Friday is brain fun, for curious people.

IRIDESCENT PRIVACY POLICY

Iridescent Learning is committed to protecting your privacy online. To further this commitment, we have adopted a Privacy Policy to guide how we collect, store, and use information obtained from customers who visit Curiositymachine.org. Part I of this Privacy Policy specifically pertains to information that may be collected when individuals who are ages 13 and older visit Curiositymachine.org. Part II specifically pertains to information that may be collected when children who are under age 13 visit Curiositymachine. org. The remainder, Parts III through IX, pertain to all Curiositymachine.org users.

I. Information We Collect From Individuals 13 Years Old and Older

A. What Information Does Curiositymachine.org Collect from You?

1. Personally Identifiable Information

To enhance your experience on Curiositymachine.org, we collect personally identifiable information that you provide to us. Although you can visit many pages on our website without providing any personally identifiable information, you must provide certain information to take advantage of particular features, such as sharing your inventions, receiving feedback from our engineers, receiving badges, and participating in project competitions.

Curiositymachine.org collects personally identifiable information that includes, but is not limited to:
Name
Address
E-Mail Address
Telephone Number
Date of Birth
Gender
Parents’ Names and E-Mail Addresses (for minors ages 13 through 17)

We collect this personally identifiable information from you when you register on Curiositymachine. org or request products or services that Curiositymachine.org offers. We also collect this information to provide you with information about science and engineering programs that might interest you. You may be asked to provide personally identifiable information if you participate in any sweepstakes, contests, or surveys, or if you post or access any content on message boards, chat rooms, or blogs at Curiositymachine. org.

2. Non-Personally Identifiable Information

Curiositymachine.org also collects non-personally identifiable information automatically through the use of electronic tools such as “cookies”. Cookies help provide a customized web experience by enabling us to identify web users who visit our website. You may choose not to provide such information by adjusting your Internet browser security settings to refuse cookies. Refusing cookies, however, may limit your ability to access certain pages available on Curiositymachine.org and may prevent you from enjoying the features on our website enabled by cookies.

B. What Do We Do with Information We Collect from You?

We may use your contact information, including your e-mail address, to communicate with you regarding products, features, and services available through Curiosity Machine or about products, features, and services that are offered by our affiliates and business partners. We may also use your contact information to send e-mail newsletters on other topics we think you might find of interest. Personally identifiable information may also be shared with marketing, advertising, or research companies.

Personally identifiable information that Curiositymachine.org collects may also be used for other purposes, including, but not limited to, website administration and troubleshooting. Third-party service providers who provide technical support for the operation of our website and assist us in providing products and services that you have requested may access personally identifiable information for these purposes.

Curiositymachine.org does not allow other parties to independently collect personally identifiable information about users’ online activities over time and across different websites.

Curiosity Machine may also share personally identifiable information under the following circumstances: (1) when we believe in good faith that the law requires it (and/or if compelled to do so by law enforcement or government agencies, or by other legal action); (2) when we deem it appropriate or necessary to provide such information to law enforcement authorities; (3) in connection with payments you may owe to us; (4) in the course of a sale to or merger with another business; or (5) in the event of a bankruptcy, in which case the information about the website’s subscribers would be among the assets shared with or transferred to another business.

C. How Can You Control the Information We Collect About You?

You can always choose not to submit your personally identifiable information to Curiosity Machine, but if you do not submit personal information, you may not be able to access many of the features, products, programs, and services that we offer.

If you do not wish to receive e-mail messages from curiositymachine.org about features, products, programs, or services that may be of interest, you can unsubscribe at any time. We will include an opt-out web link or reply e-mail address in each e-mail message. After unsubscribing, you will be removed from our e-mail database. Please allow up to 10 business days to process your request. After unsubscribing, you may still receive e-mail messages about the status of your account, to resolve technical issues, or to confirm a new subscription.

If you wish to make changes to any personally identifiable information you have provided to us, or if you have any questions about what we do with your personally identifiable information, please contact us by sending an e-mail to Curiosity@iridescentlearning.org.

II. Information We Collect From Children Under 13

Curiositymachine.org limits the collection of personally identifiable information from children to only that which is reasonably necessary to obtain parental consent or to participate in a Curiositymachine.org program or activity after we have obtained parental consent. Curiositymachine.org is prohibited from conditioning a child’s participation in an activity at Curiositymachine.org on the disclosure of more personally identifiable information than is reasonably necessary to participate in such activity. Children under 13 years old are not allowed to subscribe or create an account without a parent or guardian’s consent.

A. Parental Consent

We require a parent or guardian to consent before a child under the age of 13 can use any Curiositymachine.org products or services or participate in any Curiositymachine.org programs or activities.

Parents can provide consent in person, online, or by fax or postal mail for their children to provide personally identifiable information to us. The parental consent enables children under 13 to access Curiositymachine. org products or services or participate in Curiositymachine.org programs or activities. The parental consent form may be downloaded from the Curiositymachine.org. Upon receipt of the parental consent form, Curiositymachine.org will send you an e-mail to confirm that your child’s account has been activated.

To provide consent by fax or postal mail, parents should fill out the parental consent form, sign it and send it to Iridescent Learning at:

Mail:
Iridescent Learning
532 W. 22nd Street
Los Angeles, CA 90007

Email:
Curiosity@IridescentLearning.org
with subject line: Parental Consent

Fax (from within North America):
(888) 519-0108
with cover sheet referencing: Parental Consent

If you have any questions about parental consent or any other aspect of our privacy policy, you can call Iridescent Learning at 213-746-4453.

Iridescent Learning is the operator of Curiositymachine.org. The above address, telephone number, fax number, and e-mail address comprise the contact information for the operators of this website.

B. What Information Do We Collect from Children Under 13?

1. Personally Identifiable Information

During the registration process, we collect the following personally identifiable information from children:
Name
Address
E-Mail Address
Telephone Number
Date of Birth
Gender
Parents’ Names and E-Mail Addresses

2. Non-Personally Identifiable Information

Curiositymachine.org also collects non-personally identifiable information automatically through the use of electronic tools such as “cookies”. Cookies help provide a customized web experience by enabling us to identify web users who visit our website. You may choose not to provide such information by adjusting your Internet browser security settings to refuse cookies. Refusing cookies, however, may limit your ability to access certain pages available on Curiositymachine.org and may prevent you from enjoying the features on our website enabled by cookies. We may merge non-personally identifiable information with personally identifiable information that we collect from children under 13. Such merged information is treated as personally identifiable information.

C. What Do We Do with Information We Collect from Children Under 13?

We may use the personally identifiable information that we collect from a child under the age of 13 to determine whether he or she is eligible to use our website, obtain consent from his or her parent, provide an interactive online experience, send newsletters and provide content that we believe that the child may be interested in or would benefit from, and fulfill requests for products or services.

We may disclose personally identifiable and/or non-personally identifiable (i.e., aggregate, anonymous) information obtained from children to affiliates, as well as third party vendors, who may generate content, provide customer service or billing services, process parental consents, and/or monitor our blog. We may also disclose personally identifiable information to licensees of Iridescent Learning programs, which may include schools or corporations that sponsor STEM programs in conjunction with Curiositymachine. org and IridescentLearning.org. Additionally, we may share personally identifiable information obtained from children with third parties for marketing, advertising, or research purposes.

Curiositymachine.org does not allow other parties to independently collect personally identifiable information about users’ online activities over time and across different websites.

Users, including children, will be able post pictures and other personally identifiable information on our website. The website will be monitored by Curiositymachine.org personnel, and any inappropriate content, pictures, or information will be deleted. Any adults who may interact with children through our website are selected by Curiositymachine. org and have agreed not to further disclose personally identifiable information that they receive from a child. Other third parties that have access to personally identifiable information have agreed to maintain the confidentiality, security, and integrity of personally identifiable information. Please note that sharing information is part of the nature of Curiositymachine.org and is integral to the operation of the website. You have a right to prohibit the transfer of your child’s personally identifiable information to third parties. If you choose to exercise this option, however, your child may not be able to enjoy many of the features that are available at Curiositymachine.org.

Curiositymachine.org may also share personally identifiable information under the following circumiridescentlearning. org curiositymachine.org stances: (1) when we believe in good faith that the law requires it (and/or if compelled to do so by law enforcement or government agencies, or by other legal action); (2) when we deem it appropriate or necessary to provide such information to law enforcement authorities; (3) in connection with payments you may owe to us; (4) in the course of a sale to or merger or substantively similar transaction with another business; or (5) in the event of a bankruptcy, in which case the information about the website’s subscribers would be among the assets shared with or transferred to another business.

D. How Can You Control Information We Collect about Children Under 13?

You can review your child’s personal information at any time. You can also have your child’s personal information deleted and refuse to permit further collection of such information by us. You may revoke consent to collect your child’s personally identifiable information at any time. If you wish to review, modify, or delete any information concerning your child, please e-mail your concerns to Curiosity@IridescentLearning. org. Upon receipt of the e-mail, we will verify the parent or guardian’s authorized signature and process your request. Please allow three business days for the request to be processed.

III. Right to Be Forgotten

Pursuant to California Business and Professional Code § 22581, children under 18 may remove or request removal of information that they posted on Curiositymachine.org (in other words, information that they previously made available to users besides themselves). If you are under 18 and you wish to remove or request removal of your posted information, access your profile page and click on Delete to remove each of your challenges’ submissions. Please note that following this procedure does not ensure complete or comprehensive removal of the content or information posted on Curiositymachine.org.

IV. Third Party Links

This Privacy Policy applies solely to the collection of personally identifiable information at Curiositymachine. org. To the extent that Curiositymachine.org permits you to link to other content or advertisements that may be housed at other websites, separate privacy policies may apply to those linked websites. Your access to and use of such linked websites through links provided on this website are not governed by this Privacy Policy but, instead, are governed by the privacy policies of those linked websites.

Curiositymachine.org is not responsible for your access to and use of such linked websites, which includes any use of the personally identifiable information that you may provide to, or any personally identifiable information that may be collected about you, at such linked websites.

V. Security

To prevent unauthorized access, maintain data accuracy, and ensure the appropriate use of personally identifiable information, we have put in place physical, electronic, and administrative procedures to protect the personally identifiable information we collect online. No data transmission over the Internet, however, can be guaranteed to be completely secure. While we strive to protect your personally identifiable information, Curiositymachine.org cannot completely ensure or warrant the security of personally identifiable information you provide to us.

VI. “Do Not Track” Signals

“Do Not Track” is a feature of some internet browsers, including Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Safari, that allows users to control the tracking of their browsing activities across websites. Because Curiositymachine. org does not track users’ browsing activities on other websites, it does not respond to browsers’ “Do Not Track” signals.

VII. Changes to Privacy Policy

Curiositymachine.org reserves the right to change this policy at any time. Please check this page periodically for changes. We will post a notice on this website if and when this policy changes to alert visitors that a new policy is in place. Information collected prior to the time any change is posted will be used according to the privacy policy and applicable laws in place at the time the information was collected. Your continued use of Curiositymachine.org indicates your acceptance of the updated Privacy Policy.

VIII. Your California Privacy Rights

If you reside in California, you may request information about our disclosures of your personally identifiable information to third parties for their direct marketing purposes. Such requests must be submitted to us by e-mail at Curiosity@IridescentLearning.org.

Within thirty days of receiving such a request, we will provide a list of the categories of personally identifiable information disclosed to third-parties for direct marketing purposes during the immediately preceding calendar year, along with the names and addresses of these third parties. This request may be made no more than once per calendar year. We reserve the right not to respond to requests submitted other than as specified in the above paragraph.

IX. Effective Date

This Privacy Policy is effective as of June 30 2014.

Build your own Curiosity Machine community!

Curiosity Machine is a resource you can use to inspire students to become inventors while they build Engineering Design Challenges. Anyone with a passion for learning and exploration can build a Curiosity Machine community--no science background is necessary!


Curiosity Machine features:

  • Free access to science and engineering content and Engineering Design Challenges that anyone can facilitate with simple materials
  • Connection to virtual science and engineering mentors who give individualized feedback and inspire children to improve their designs
  • A fun way to engage parents in their children’s learning and encourage families to do science together

Ready to get started?

Fill out our Educator Form and our team will be in contact shortly!

Download our Curiosity Kit to learn more about:

  • The Engineering Design Process
  • Our Mentoring Philosophy
  • Curiosity Machine Planning Guidelines
  • Suggested Design Challenges
  • Website Walkthrough




Even More Curiosity Machine Resources:

fields.text:
Help inspire the next generation of inventors!

Curiosity Machine connects scientists and engineers with children, inspiring them to be persistent, creative, and curious inventors.


Mission

Our scientist and engineer mentors provide encouraging and content-rich feedback to children, helping them learn science content and encourage them to persist as they build Engineering Design Challenges.

Flexible & Accessible Mentoring

  • 1 hour a week commitment
  • provide feedback from anywhere and at anytime
  • connect with & empower young learners in your local community
  • improve your science communication & mentoring skills

"I love encouraging young people to be world class creative and critical thinkers and ultimately problem solvers. Love hearing and seeing their ideas and encouraging them along the way." - Fall 2014 Mentor


.

Learn more in our STEM Mentor Experience flyer and watching the Curiosity Machine Mission video above.

To become a mentor on the Curiosity Machine, please go the homepage, select the Get Started! then the Become a Mentor button and create a mentor account.

fields.text:
Play inspired by the work of scientists and engineers!

Curiosity Machine is a space where children can learn and invent with the support of science and engineering experts.


To join our community, help your child create an account and explore the Engineering Design Challenges. Your child’s Curiosity Machine account will serve as a digital portfolio for his or her drawings, text, and videos of completed Engineering Design Challenges, as well as provide access to trained mentors who will support the learning process.


Any parent with a passion for learning and exploration can use Curiosity Machine with their child to learn science and engineering. No science background is necessary!

Ready to get Started?

Download our Curiosity Kit to learn more about:

  • How to build your child's problem solving skills
  • The Value in Making Mistakes
  • How to ask Challenging Questions
  • How to organize your own Curiosity Party


Compilation of resources you can use while you have fun building with your child:




Why build Engineering Design Challenges?

The more children build and redesign their models, the more comfortable they'll become with the Engineering Design Process that professional scientists and engineers use to solve complex problems every day. This greater comfort with failure and re-design will help children persist through all manner of problems, not just those related to science and engineering. Learn more how this process works:

Have a designated night each week for your family to build together.

You can use these times to model for your child how to be persistent and imaginative! These nights can also be a great way for you to encourage an atmosphere of learning in your home.


Organize a Curiosity Machine Party with your child’s friends!

Choose an Engineering Design Challenge, gather materials, and be sure to have access to a tablet or a phone with internet so children can upload their work. Building socially is always more creative and fun! Here is the invitation!

fields.text:
Curiosity Machine FAQ

  • Learning Philosophy
  • Using Curiosity Machine
  • Parents
  • Educators
  • Mentors

Learning Philosophy

Who is Curiosity Machine for?

Our engineering design challenges are open-ended and appropriate for children K-12. With the support of a parent, even young children can navigate the site, upload their designs, and become inventors in the Curiosity Machine community!


What does it cost to use Curiosity Machine?

Curiosity Machine is a free and open tool. Anyone can create an account and use all Curiosity Machine features, and our engineering design challenges can be completed with simple, low cost materials.


What kind of technology do I need to use Curiosity Machine?

You can access the Curiosity Machine and our online community of mentors on any smartphone, tablet, or computer with a browser and internet access. Ideally, your device has a built-in camera to take photos and videos as you move through the engineering design process (you can also use a digital camera and upload photos to your device).

Find more technology recommendations on page 7 of our Curiosity Kit.


What are engineering design challenges?

We believe children learn by building. Engineering design challenges are hands-on projects inspired by the cutting-edge work of scientists and engineers. In each challenge, children are presented with a complex problem to solve, and they progress with support from a trained mentor who guides and encourages them to persist through failure and bring their ideas to reality.


How long does it take to complete an engineering design challenge?

Most design challenges will take about 90 minutes to plan, build, test, and submit to the site for mentor feedback. A mentor will respond within 3-5 days, and then you can start the redesign process! The redesign process can go on for as long as you can make improvements to the design--and the same mentor will be ready to offer feedback on every change you make.


Should Curiosity Machine engineering design challenges be completed in sequence?

Our design challenges do not need to be completed in any particular order. If you’re looking for ideas of what challenge to do next, try focusing on a particular theme (like Aerospace or Civil Engineering), or follow one of our suggested series!


Who are Curiosity Machine mentors? How will they help my child?

Mentors are professional scientists and engineers from all over the world who are dedicated to inspiring the next generation of inventors.

All of our mentors are volunteers, choosing to use their passion to inspire others. Mentors must successfully complete training before working with any user on Curiosity Machine. This training prepares them to work with children across a range of abilities, and to foster growth mindset, persistence, creativity, and curiosity in the children they work with.

When children submit text, photos or videos of a design challenge, one of our mentors will claim their challenge and respond with feedback. Look for the orange icon on your challenge that indicates a mentor message waiting for you!


I created an account for a child under the age of 13, but the account is locked. How do I unlock this account?

Because users upload photos and videos to the Curiosity Machine, the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) requires that we obtain parental consent before activating Curiosity Machine accounts for children under the age of 13.

To unlock your child’s account please submit this consent form to curiosity@technovation.org


Where can I buy Curiosity Machine design challenge materials?

Most design challenges can be completed with simple, low-cost materials that can be obtained at a grocery or hardware store.


Using Curiosity Machine

Confused or stuck? Check out this demo video to walk through the Curiosity Machine website and learn how to submit your design challenges, view feedback, respond to feedback, and access challenges you’re still working on.


Why haven’t I received any mentor feedback for my engineering design challenge?

We try to respond to every design within 3 to 5 days after it’s submitted. Weekends and holidays or technical problems may prolong our usual response times. If it has been more than 5 days get in touch with us at curiosity@technovation.org.


What does the orange icon on my project mean?

Woohoo! That orange icon means that you have received feedback from a mentor! Select the challenge and see what you mentor has to say – and don’t forget to respond!


How do I respond to mentor feedback?

Once you have mentor feedback, you may have the option to continue to the next stage of the engineering design process. Or, you can ask your mentor for additional help and continue to improve on your design! Continue to post pictures, video, and text of your design process.


How do I see the design challenges that I am currently working on?

All of your design challenges live on your profile homepage. To get to your homepage, log in, then click on the menu tab and select “Home.” You should see all of the challenges you’re working on, as well as all the challenges you’ve completed.


Parents

I want to use Curiosity Machine at home, but I’m not a science expert. How can I support my child to learn science?

We believe you don’t need to be a scientist or engineer to help your child learn science! You also don’t need to have all the answers--when you explore and learn alongside your child, you’ll be modeling curiosity and persistence, inspiring them to ask questions and look for answers instead of giving up when they don’t know something.

Check out our resources for parents to learn more about how to support your child in our engineering design challenges.


How do I know what my child is doing?

If your child is younger than 13, your child’s account is linked to your email. If your child has received feedback from a mentor, you will get an email notification. You can also log onto your child’s account to see what engineering design challenges they have uploaded and the mentor feedback they have received.


Why is mentor feedback valuable to my child?

Mentors provide encouraging and content-rich feedback to children throughout the building process. This support helps reinforce key science concepts, but it also inspires children to be more creative and persistent as it motivates them to continue improving their designs.

Receiving feedback from a professional is a really cool experience--it feels like both a “congratulations!” and a “keep going!” Oftentimes, mentors come to occupy the place of role models for children, through interacting and problem solving as a team.


Is Curiosity Machine safe for my child to use?

Curiosity Machine takes our users’ safety very seriously. We comply with the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA), requiring parental consent for accounts for children under the age of 13. Additionally, our mentors undergo required training on interacting with children online. Please be aware that student project pictures are uploaded to the inspiration gallery, which is visible to other users.

For more information about family internet safety, we recommend the information and advice found at Common Sense Media.


Educators

How can I use Curiosity Machine at my site?

You can use Curiosity Machine any number of ways, but for group settings we recommend our Curiosity Course model. Curiosity Courses meet once a week for 5-6 weeks in 90 minute sessions, giving children time to redesign their projects using feedback from our online mentors.

Not sure which design challenges to start with? Our suggested series flyer will get you started!

Looking for more recommendations? Check out our Curiosity Kit and other educator resources.

Ready to start your own Curiosity Course? Email curiosity@technovation.org!


I’m interested in using Curiosity Machine, but I don’t have a STEM background. How do I support my students to build design challenges?

Our philosophy is that you don’t need to be a science or an engineering expert to help children learn science. If you can provide the space, materials, and encouragement for children to build, you’re well on your way to creating a meaningful learning experience. We always recommend building a design challenge yourself before facilitating it with a group; your own experience of building will help you better anticipate where your participants might struggle. When children are ready for feedback, get stuck on a part of their design, or just have a question about how something works, Curiosity Machine’s online mentors are there to support!


Is there funding available for implementing Curiosity Machine at my site?

We unfortunately do not offer funding for Curiosity Machine programs, but we strive to make our website and curriculum open and accessible to all. It’s free for anyone to create an account and use all Curiosity Machine features, and our engineering design challenges can be completed with simple, low cost materials.


Do you offer training on how to use Curiosity Machine in a classroom or after-school setting?

Yes! Our team offers professional development that supports our partners in using the website, facilitating design challenges, and creating a supportive learning environment that encourages a child’s natural curiosity, creativity, and persistence.

For information on upcoming webinars, sign up for our educator news.

For inquiries about in-person or online trainings, email curiosity@technovation.org.

Mentors

How do I become a Curiosity Machine mentor?

Learn more and sign up on our Mentor page.


What are the benefits of becoming a Curiosity Machine mentor?

Help inspire the next generation of inventors while improving your science communication and mentoring skills! Curiosity Machine mentors are recognized for their role in supporting the learning of youth by Iridescent and our partners including Boeing, Google, Intel, and NSF.


What is the time commitment required to become a mentor?

We ask mentors to volunteer 1 hour a week, which equates to evaluating & providing feedback on two student projects.


Are there in-person mentoring opportunities available?

Mentoring in-person at the Curiosity Courses is both fun and rewarding! If you are located in LA, NYC, Chicago, or San Francisco please contact us for more information on joining.



Didn’t find an answer to your question? Email it to curiosity@technovation.org!
